Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel Hybrid Inorganic-organic Tandem Junction Solar cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The objective of this EAGER project is to rapidly increase the efficiency and stability of organic solar cells by combining them with an inorganic solar cell in a tandem or multiple junction arrangement and do the fundamental device research needed to get over 10% stable efficiency. Achieving higher efficiency and stability simultaneously is a critical need in the field of organic solar cells. The project is based on the very recent invention by the PI of a tandem junction comprising inorganic and organic solar cells which increased the conversion efficiency and the stability compared to the organic cell by itself.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: 14.00 Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Project outcomes report: Intellectual merit: The objective of this EAGER project was to develop an alternative hybrid device structure combining an inorganic and an organic solar cell for increasing the efficiency of solar energy conversion into electricity. Another objective was to develop a better understanding of the device physics of instability in organic solar cells. During this project, we developed a hybrid combination of an inorganic solar cell based on a-(Si,C) and an organic cell based on P3HT/PCBM bulk heterojunction. The new device increased the overall conversion efficiency of the P3HT cell from ~4.1% to ~5.6%, a 33% increase. A major innovation was the use of an inorganic intermediate ITO layer to connect the organic bottom cell with the inorganic top cell. This ITO layer allowed for an efficient ohmic contact to both the top and the bottom cells, and was instrumental in achieving the high efficiency. We also studied the physics of instability of organic solar cells. We discovered that fundamental properties of the material and device, defect density was increasing in both the bulk material(P3HT) and at the interface between the donor and the acceptor. The increase in interfacial defects led to significant increase in recombination at the interface, leading to a loss in fill factor and voltage of the solar cell after illumination. We also discovered that the organic solar cell degraded much more when subjected to a given flux of higher energy (blue) photons than an equivalent flux of lower energy (yellow) photons. Another discovery was that the degradation upon illumination was not a linear function of the total dose, but tended to saturate after a certain dose. We also discovered that the defects could be completely annealed out, and the device performance restored to its original value, by doing thermal annealing after light-induced degradation. The restoration in performance could be directly attributed to a corresponding reduction in defect density, both bulk and interfacial, upon annealing. Broader Impact: The project had a significant impact on the education of undergraduate and graduate students in engineering. A Ph.D. student graduated with partial support from this grant. Several undergraduate students received research training on solar cell material and device fabrication and analysis with partial support from this grant. In addition, a post-doctoral scientist was mentored under this project. Many talks were presented at International Conferences to scientific audiences on the topic of hybrid tandem cells and physics of instability of organic cells. The talks were presented both in the U.S. and abroad (in India and Canada). Several talks were given to non-scientific audiences on the role of solar energy in worldÃ†s energy economy. Four journal publications and several conference proceedings articles were published with partial support from this grant. The new technology developed, and the research on understanding of the physics of instability of organic solar cells, are likely to have a significant impact on improving the performance and stability of organic solar cells for widespread application in the future. Last Modified: 03/03/2014 Submitted by: Vikram L Dalal
